name: sfchronicle
text: Update: The two-acre wildland fire was contained shortly after 4 p.m. SFPD said there were no injuries reported or damage to structures. https://t.co/K5lvX7J4ZL

name: sfchronicle
text: As the pandemic wears on and communities learn to live with the coronavirus, small get-togethers with family and close friends seem reasonable, many health experts have said. As long as people are careful. https://t.co/DlbDF664oC

name: sfchronicle
text: We rounded up the best advice from health experts and the AAA on what to include in a road trip checklist for the COVID-19 era: items to pack, must-dos ahead of the trip, and safety steps to take while on the road. https://t.co/CH8jkiMCxx

name: sfchronicle
text: Reopening too soon? For the seven-day period through Thursday, cases in Sonoma County rose 41% from the previous seven-day period, to 803. Napa County saw an 11% increase, to 206 cases, in that time. https://t.co/eu8KlR8CQe

name: sfchronicle
text:
Contra Costa County health officials reported 93 new cases of the coronavirus on Saturday ‚Äî by far its highest tally since the pandemic began. 

Previously, the highest number was 68 new cases, recorded on June 9. https://t.co/cHZz4jylpE

name: sfchronicle
text: When did the shelter-in-place order begin -- and for which Bay Area counties? What businesses can reopen? Get the full timeline here: https://t.co/xD8Th1vigN

name: sfchronicle
text:
Several hundred people marched down Market St., from the Ferry Building to City Hall ‚Äî a day after demonstrators toppled historical figures in Golden Gate Park ‚Äî where artists painted ‚ÄúDefund the Police‚Äù and ‚ÄúBLM" outside. 

Read more: https://t.co/FKx80Hx9L1 https://t.co/GtpSt3Kl5W

name: sfchronicle
text:
At his rally in Tulsa, President Trump said he asked to "slow the testing down." 

"When you do testing to that extent, you're going to find more people, you're going to find more cases. So I said to my people, 'Slow the testing down, please.'" 

https://t.co/wQ4vyUR4it

name: sfchronicle
text:
JUST IN: Vallejo police are investigating a suspected murder after an adult male died Friday night from at least one gunshot wound.

The death marks the city's 12th murder of 2020 and comes at a difficult time for the police department. https://t.co/giF45vWTPX https://t.co/hrXAsB26MW

name: sfchronicle
text:
West Contra Costa Unified School District officials are asking families to fill out an anonymous survey about their experiences with distance learning.

‚ÄúAs we navigate uncertainty due to the COVID-19 pandemic, your voice matters," officials said.

https://t.co/yLSL39iV8i

name: sfchronicle
text:
St. Helena city officials announced that a mobile testing site will open to everyone who lives or works in the city. 

Testing is open to everyone, even people without coronavirus symptoms. The site will be open Monday and Tuesday (June 22-23).

https://t.co/FVBd6ekNI5

name: sfchronicle
text:
30 people were hospitalized with COVID-19 in San Francisco as of Friday ‚Äî the lowest figure for the city since at least March. The figure had been as high as 90 in early April. 

For more data, visit our Virus Tracker: https://t.co/ritmMhcaSB

name: sfchronicle
text: ‚ÄúEvery dollar we spend cleaning up this vandalism takes funding away from actually supporting our community, including our African American community,‚Äù Mayor London Breed said. https://t.co/lv1YWfH5Ws

name: sfchronicle
text: Assemblyman Phil Ting denied published allegations that an extramarital affair had influenced his work as a legislator. He apologized to his family and constituents for not being faithful to his wife. https://t.co/jCGR8NU4BV

name: sfchronicle
text:
Looking to eat outside this weekend? Here's a list of more than 140 Bay Area restaurants that are now open for outdoor dining.

https://t.co/gPiKvDrZ0x

name: sfchronicle
text: The statewide shortage of California Lottery Scratchers could result in millions of dollars in lost revenue. Reporter @ctuan takes a look at the impact, including how that might affect public schools: https://t.co/fZ4ZgFzjfu

name: sfchronicle
text: Today's front page: the stories San Francisco is talking about this morning. https://t.co/sgK7iFvtYo https://t.co/IdhFWwpvQg

name: sfchronicle
text: The San Francisco Public Utilities Commission is preparing to sell the 16-acre Balboa Reservoir property to a private development group for $11.4 million, reports @SFjkdineen. https://t.co/leYEs9k9Pk

name: sfchronicle
text:
It's been around 100 days since the Bay Area began sheltering in place, bringing life here to a standstill. 

After months of reporting on the virus, here's what The Chronicle does know: https://t.co/GJ4h8MulOr

name: sfchronicle
text:
David Perlman loved everything about newspapers, and he was intensely proud that most of his career was spent in San Francisco, covering science for The Chronicle.

He died on Friday. He was 101.

Read his obituary:
https://t.co/ZCfXUna0Tc

name: sfchronicle
text:
Low-income people of color are getting sick and dying from COVID-19 more than other groups in the Bay Area.
